body.p:
I received a few days ago your kind
letter, coverring the proof of an article, which
you propose to publish in the next Occident;
and although you do not exactly ask my
advice, I am led to infer that you desire it,
by the fact that you sent me the “proof.”
I would publish no article on the subject, nor
would I allude to it in any manner what=
soever, either in print, or in conversation.
You have been badly treated, but neither writing
nor talking will mend the mend? the matter, or place
you in status quo. Why then write? It will give
pain to your real friends, who will think it indig=
nified and pleasure to your enemies, who will
thereby see, & know that you are mortified. Silence
will, I think, produce a reaction. I am sure it
will make you friends, and that it will be more
dignified. Men should never act without an
object, and what do you propose to effect by your
proposed article. If however you think otherwise
I pray you strike out those words I have passed
my pen through. I think you wrong to have any

feeling against Mr. DeSola, or Dr. Raphall. It was no
breach of friendship in the former becoming a
candidate, when applications were invited by pub=
=lic advertisement; and you must admit that his
offering neither injured, nor benefitted you. Your
enemies were determined to put you down the
same crew had been striving for that object for
twenty five years, and the wonder is that you
held your ground so long. Now as to Dr. Rs. Giving
a certificate of qualification, I have no hesi=
=tancy in saying that he, and every other man
is bound by every principle of honor, and duty
to give such a certificate whenever called on to
do so, if the party is capable. I have given cer=
=tificates of qualification, when at the same
time I desired an other equally capable to
receive the appointment. Try, my friend, to
think differently of mankind—do not, I pray you,
suppose that every body is against you. There
is good and evil in this world—and all of us have
our respective shares. You may remember
an anecdote of Dr. Franklin. When about leaving
Boston for his voyage of life, he went to see an old
friend, who at his departure took him through
a dark passage by which he struck his head against
a beam. The old man said, let this teach you
that you must often stoop if you want to
pass through life without difficulty. Franklin
took the hint, & you know his history.

Now I, by no means, intend to advise, a mean, time
serving policy: being all things unto all men
we should have fixed principles, and should adhere to
them at every hazzard. But there are many things
in which principle is not involved, and then it is
not only our right but it is our duty (if we desire
success) to use the suaviter? in modo to flatter
(not at the expense of principle) the petty vanities of
those among whom we live and to bend these very
follies to our own use. If a man wants to be servic-
able in his calling—be it what it may—he
must command the love and respect of those
among whom his lot is cast; and to do this
he must be firm—honest & honorable—and he
must also yield to their wishes in minor things.
But excuse me. I may perhaps tire you, but at
any rate be assured that all that I do say
is prompted by a sincere friendship and a
desire for your welfare & happiness.

I would beg you to be sure of success before
you undertake any of the new works you now
propose. Continue if possible the Occident.
Send it hereafter to Mr. D. L. Cohen, Savannah Geo.
who you may put down as a permanent, paying
subscriber. My family join in kindest regards.
